name: Asobombo Colombia

Founded in 2013, modcup coffee focuses on fresh roasting and distinctive natural-processed coffees. This special release is available to members of modcup’s Deepcuts list. name: Colombia Wilton Benitez Striped Bourbon Thermal Shock
desc_1: Bright, juicy, floral-toned. Tangerine, plumeria (frangipani) red plum, cocoa nib, tarragon in aroma and cup. Sparkling (phosphoric) acidity; delicately satiny, very smooth mouthfeel. The resonant finish carries over all the flavor notes from the cup.
desc_2: Produced by Wilton Benitez of Granja Paraiso 92, entirely of the Striped Bourbon variety of Arabica, and processed by the double-anaerobic thermal shock method, in which the coffee fruit, after having been first sanitized with ozone, undergoes two stages of fermentation. First, the whole cherries are submerged under water for 48 hours, then the beans are pulped and fermented with wine yeasts. Founded in 2013, modcup coffee focuses on fresh roasting and distinctive natural-processed coffees. Visit modcup.com for more information.
desc_3: This is a coffee that balances bright citrus, sweet florals and rich herbs with aplomb — it’s got a compelling intrigue very much worth pursuing.Explore Similar CoffeesClick here for more reviews from modcupClick here for more information about coffees from ColombiaVisit modcup

name: Ethiopia Mulish

desc_2: Produced by smallholding farmers, from local landrace varieties of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). Temple Coffee is a quality-focused retail and wholesale specialty roaster active in Sacramento, California since 2005. Committed to sourcing, roasting and brewing the finest coffees, Temple features selections from distinguished single estates and cooperatives around the world. Visit www.templecoffee.com or call 916-454-1282 for more information.
desc_3: A multi-layered, flavor-laden washed Ethiopia with leading notes of cocoa nib, sweet herbs, and complex citrus.Explore Similar CoffeesClick here for more reviews from Temple CoffeeClick here for more information about coffees from EthiopiaVisit Temple Coffee

name: Ethiopia Gesha Village Oma Gesha 1931 Natural
desc_1: Lush, floral, deeply aromatic, floral-toned. Wisteria, pink peppercorn, dried mango, bergamot, cocoa nib  in aroma and cup. Delicately bright, vibrant acidity; full, syrupy smooth mouthfeel. Crisp, floral finish with undertones of pink peppercorn.
desc_2: Produced from trees of the rare Ethiopia-derived botanical variety Gesha (also Geisha) by Adam and Rachel Overton. With its generally elongated beans and distinctive floral and crisp, often chocolaty cup, the Gesha variety continues to distinguish itself as one of the world’s most unique coffees. Although the Gesha variety originated in Ethiopia, it was “discovered” by the coffee world in 2004 growing in Boquete, Panama, and Panama continues to dominate the expanding world of Gesha. This particular version, however, is the outcome of efforts to commercialize Gesha in the region from which it originally came. It is processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). Buon Caffe is a specialty coffee roaster and cafe in Taipei, Taiwan. Visit www.buoncaffe.com.tw for more information.
desc_3: A complex, decadently sweet, flavor-saturated Ethiopia Geisha — bright, deep, satiating, lyrical.Explore Similar CoffeesClick here for more reviews from Buon CaffeClick here for more information about coffees from EthiopiaVisit Buon Caffe

name: Kenya Gatirima AA

name: Ethiopia Natural Sidama Espresso
desc_1: Evaluated as espresso. Lychee, caramel, hazelnut butter, redwood, brown sugar in aroma and small cup. Creamy-smooth mouthfeel; integrated, coherent finish. In three parts milk, all of the notes from the straight shot carry over and freesia also emerges.

Kakalove Café is a nano-roaster located in the small city of Chia-Yi in Taiwan that strives to procure and roast the finest quality coffee. name: Guatemala Honey Finca El General Gesha

name: Ethiopia Natural Sidama Bacha 74110
desc_1: Crisp, juicy, high-toned. Dried mango, cocoa nib, lemon balm, thyme, magnolia in aroma and cup. Sweetly tart, green apple-like acidity; vibrantly silky mouthfeel. Fruit-forward finish, cocoa-toned, and supported by rich florals and sweet herbs.

name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Adame G1 Washed 95
desc_1: Rich-toned, flavor-saturated. Black currant, magnolia, dark chocolate, candied walnut, hint of smoked paprika in aroma and cup. Sweet-savory structure with elegantly juicy acidity; syrupy-smooth mouthfeel. Richly chocolaty finish with undertones of black currant and candied walnut.

desc_3: Deeply aromatic, complex and rich, this G1-washed Yirgacheffe delivers in all categories with its balanced brightness, viscosity and interesting smoky spice note (unrelated to roast).Explore Similar CoffeesClick here for more reviews from Buon CaffeClick here for more information about coffees from EthiopiaVisit Buon Caffe

name: Colombia Linarco Rodriguez Ospina Pink Bourbon Washed 94
desc_1: Delicately bright, balanced, richly sweet-tart. Red plum and cocoa nib in the aroma, deepening into Meyer lemon zest, shortbread and lilac in the cup. Gently bright, vibrant acidity; plush, silky mouthfeel. Very rich, multi-layered finish, deeply aromatic finish.

Buon Caffe is a specialty coffee roaster and cafe in Taipei, Taiwan. Visit www.buoncaffe.com.tw for more information.
desc_3: An unassuming initial break opens up on the table with big florals, stone fruit and complex citrus notes throughout the cup and into the very long finish.

name: Ethiopia Guji Uraga Haro Adama Washed G1
desc_1: Richly sweet, spice-toned. Bergamot, pistachio, dark chocolate, lilac, honey in aroma and cup. Sweetly tart with juicy acidity; very silky mouthfeel. The chocolaty supports top notes of bergamot and lilac.

name: Ecuador Mejorado Washed
desc_1: Very sweet, crisply chocolaty. Baking chocolate, red apple, maple syrup, bay leaf, clover blossom in aroma and cup. Briskly sweet acidity; very syrupy, vibrant mouthfeel. The finish centers around notes of baking chocolate and sweet red apple.

desc_3: A lively, chocolate- and herb-driven washed Ecuador with a throughline of red apple notes supported by crisp maple syrup.

name: Colombia Edwin Enrique Noreña / Black Honey Watermelon & Lulo Co-Ferment
desc_1: Nectar-like, sweetly tart, rich-toned. Watermelon candy, cocoa butter, loquat, freesia, graphite in aroma and cup. High-toned, phosphoric acidity; syrupy-smooth mouthfeel. Sweet, long, candy-like finish
desc_2: Produced by Edwin Enrique Noreñ of Finca Campo Hermoso, entirely of the Castillo variety of Arabica, and processed by carbonic maceration (which involves fermenting the whole fruit in a sealed container that has been flushed with CO2) and co-fermenting with watermelon and lulo, then dried with most of the fruit flesh remaining on the beans. Produced by Edwin Enrique Noreña, Little Waves Coffee is a Latina-owned, women-forward company that provides livable wages for its diverse team. Visit www.littlewaves.coffee for more information.
desc_3: Candy-sweet in its profile, this co-fermented Colombia Castillo evokes the tropics with a side of spicy florals.

name: Colombia Edwin Enrique Noreña / Black Honey Pink Bourbon Mosto & Passionfruit Co-Ferment
desc_1: Tropical, deep, harmonious. Passionfruit, star jasmine, myrrh, cocoa nib, pineapple saltwater taffy in aroma and cup. Bright, juicy acidity; crisp, syrupy mouthfeel. Resonantly fruity and floral finish.
desc_2: Produced by Edwin Enrique Noreñ of Finca Campo Hermoso, entirely of the Castillo variety of Arabica, and processed by carbonic maceration (which involves fermenting the whole fruit in a sealed container that has been flushed with CO2) and co-fermenting with Pink Bourbon mosto and passionfruit, then dried with most of the fruit flesh remaining on the beans. Little Waves Coffee is a Latina-owned, women-forward company that provides livable wages for its diverse team. Visit www.littlewaves.coffee for more information.

name: Colombia Edwin Enrique Noreña Juice Box Processing Set / Natural Carbonic Maceration
desc_1: Floral-toned, very, very sweet. Tea rose, candied apple, agave syrup, dark chocolate, orange marmalade in aroma and cup. Gently brisk acidity; creamy-smooth mouthfeel. Citrusy finish with undertones of tea rose.

Little Waves Coffee is a Latina-owned, women-forward company that provides livable wages for its diverse team. Visit www.littlewaves.coffee for more information.
desc_3: A richly floral, incredibly sweet carbonic macerated Colombia with tea rose notes at center, supported by orange marmalade.

name: Colombia Edwin Enrique Noreña Pink Bourbon
desc_1: Flavor-laden, aromatically exuberant. Passionfruit, elderberry, lemon-thyme, pomelo, cocoa nib in aroma and cup. Juicy-bright acidity; very full, syrupy mouthfeel. Tropical finish with fruit and sweet herb notes front and center.
desc_2: Produced by Edwin Enrique Noreña of Finca Campo Hermoso, entirely of the Pink Bourbon variety of Arabica, and processed by carbonic maceration (which involves fermenting the whole fruit in a sealed container that has been flushed with CO2) and co-fermented with mixed berries and passionfruit, and dried with most of the fruit flesh remaining on the beans. name: Thailand Quiet Endless Searching Natural

name: Rwanda Humure Abishyizehamwe Low-Oxygen Natural
origin: Remera Sector, Gatsibo District, Eastern Province, Rwanda

desc_1: Richly sweet, delicately tart. Tamarind, dried mango, cocoa nib, marjoram, cedar in aroma and cup. Briskly sweet, gentle acidity; full, syrupy smooth mouthfeel. Crisp, sweetly tart finish.

name: Euphora Plumeria Cold Brew
desc_1: A ready-to-drink black coffee, tested cold. Floral-toned, sweetly tart. Bing cherry, ginger, wisteria, pink grapefruit zest, allspice. High-toned, juicy acidity; light, crisp mouthfeel. name: Colombia El Paraiso Lychee Rose Cold Drip
desc_1: A ready-to-drink black coffee, tested cold. Deep-toned, rich-tart-savory. Asian pear, pipe tobacco, pink peppercorn, blood orange, cocoa nib. desc_2: Prepared by the cold-drip method, in which a controlled dripper brews the coffee over 4-6 hours in the refrigerator, at a coffee to water ratio of 1:15. which involves prolonged steeping of ground coffee in cold water. GK Coffee is a nano-roastery in Yilan, Taiwan that offers both retail and wholesale coffee. For more information, visit www.gkcoffee.com.tw or email [email protected].

name: Ethiopia Halo Hartume
desc_1: A ready-to-drink black coffee, tested cold. Brightly fruit-forward. Guava, magnolia, baking chocolate, lemon-thyme, cedar. Crisp, citrusy acidity; velvety-smooth mouthfeel. desc_2: Brewed hot, then chilled quickly without exposure to oxygen before being canned. Contains no additives or ingredients other than coffee and water. The green coffee used is a single-origin Ethiopia from the Yirgacheffe growing region, wash-processed. Four Barrel is a café in San Francisco's Mission District with an in-house roasting facility. Visit www.fourbarrelcoffee.com or call 415-252-0800 for more information.

name: Cold Brew
desc_1: A ready-to-drink black coffee, tested cold. Balanced, crisply chocolaty, sweetly nutty. Baking chocolate, hazelnut, rhododendron, fresh-cut oak, tangerine zest. Gentle, round acidity; very full, satiny-smooth mouthfeel. Nut-driven finish with tangerine undertones. With a splash of milk, kind of like a Snickers bar with hazelnuts instead of almonds.
desc_2: Produced by Cool Crafted Beverage in a proprietary process that involves steeping a precise dose of coffee in mineral-enhanced water of a precise (undisclosed) temperature, then cooling and canning. The green coffee used is Olympia’s Morning Sun blend, sourced from small farmers throughout Latin America. Contains no additives or ingredients other than coffee and water. Olympia Coffee Roasting is a small-batch wholesale and retail roasting company with a youthful, no-nonsense style and a commitment to high-quality organic coffees. Visit www.olympiacoffee.com or call 360-753-0066 for more information.
desc_3: If there’s such a thing as a “classic” cold brew, this might be it, with foregrounded notes of chocolate and hazelnut and a backdrop of vaExplore Similar CoffeesClick here for more reviews from Olympia Coffee Roasting Co.

name: Montecarlos Snapchill Coffee
desc_1: A ready-to-drink black coffee, tested cold. Crisply cocoa-toned, sweetly nutty. Cocoa powder, walnut, Valencia orange, bay leaf, caramel. Juicy, malic (apple-like) acidity; velvety mouthfeel. Richly bittersweet, walnutty and cocoa-toned finish. With milk, cocoa notes are amplified and walnut tones sweeten.
desc_2: Produced by Snapchill in a proprietary process that involves brewing the coffee hot, then immediately chilling it to 38 degrees to prevent oxidation. Contains no additives or ingredients other than coffee and water. Founded by George Howell in Boston in 2004, George Howell Coffee now operates three cafes and a roastery. Visit www.georgehowellcoffee.com for more information.
desc_3: A balanced, inviting single-origin El Salvador in cold-brew format: cocoa-toned, crisply nutty, with especially bright, juicy acidity that stands up to milk.

name: Extra Strong Cold Brew Straight Black
desc_1: A ready-to-drink black coffee, tested cold. Deep-toned, flavor-saturated. Dark chocolate, date, cashew butter, vanilla bean, pink grapefruit zest. Gentle, sweetly brisk acidity; crisp, silky mouthfeel. Chocolaty finish supported by date and pink grapefruit zest. With milk, surprisingly bright — zest pink grapefruit is front and center with dark chocolate and date undertones.
desc_2: Comprised of certified USDA Organic washed-process coffees from Peru, Mexico and Nicaragua, produced by a proprietary cold-brew method and flash-pasteurized for shelf stability prior to opening. Contains no additives or ingredients other than coffee and water. Wandering Bear was founded in 2014 with the mission of producing strong, smooth, organic-certified cold brew in recyclable packaging. Visit www.wanderingbearcoffee.com for more information.
desc_3: A solid, classic-style cold brew: richly chocolaty, sweetly nutty, with deep fruit and delicately bright citrus notes.

name: Nice Nitro Organic Black Cold Brew Coffee
desc_1: A ready-to-drink black coffee, tested cold. Deep-toned, balanced. Date, salted caramel, walnut, orange zest, gently smoky cedar. Round, smooth acidity; crisp, fluffy mouthfeel. Richly bittersweet finish driven by walnut and orange zest notes. Slightly smoky cedar notes play nicely with milk, alongside date, salted caramel and walnut.
desc_2: A blend of Fair Trade Organic coffees from Colombia, Nicaragua, Honduras and Indonesia, cold-brewed for 24 hours at a ratio of one pound of coffee per gallon of water, and infused with nitrogen. Visit www.deansbeans.com or call 800-325-3008 for more information.

name: Nitro Cold Brew Decaf Coffee
desc_1: A ready-to-drink black coffee, tested cold. Sweet-toned, caramelly. Dark caramel, cocoa nib, lemon verbena, fresh-cut fir, nutmeg. Briskly sweet acidity; wood-framed, sweetly caramelly finish. Complex caramel notes dominate when milk is added, complementing the lingering lemon verbena and nutmeg.
desc_2: Comprised of coffees decaffeinated by the Select Water Process (origin undisclosed) and produced by Quivr using a proprietary cold-brew method, then infused with nitrogen. Contains no additives or ingredients other than coffee and water. Quivr is a Boston-based company founded by Ash Crawford and Mukunda Feldman to produce a range of coffee and tea products that are ethically sourced and high-quality. Visit www.drinkquivr.com for more information.
desc_3: An exceptional decaf nitro cold brew — caramel-toned, sweetly herbaceous, citrusy — especially appealing with milk.

name: Bold Cold Brewed Coffee
desc_1: A ready-to-drink black coffee, tested cold. Crisply sweet-savory. Baking chocolate, hop flowers, Brazil nut, almond, gently scorched oak. Round, quiet acidity; velvety mouthfeel. Nut-driven finish with bittersweet floral undertones. Pleasantly and gently smoky with milk, with nice notes of bittersweet florals and baking chocolate.
desc_2: Central American coffees from undisclosed countries are cold-brewed by a proprietary process, then filtered and canned. Blue Bottle Coffee is a specialty roaster with cafes in Los Angeles, San Francisco, New York and Japan now owned by Nestlé S.A. Visit www.bluebottlecoffee.com for more information.
desc_3: A crisply chocolaty, sweetly nutty cold brew with a hop-like bittersweet floral throughline.

name: Colombia Finca La Secreta Lychee Caturra Anaerobic
desc_1: Floral-toned, richly fruity. Wisteria, lychee, kumquat, cocoa nib, marjoram in aroma and cup. High-toned, juicy acidity; viscous, syrupy mouthfeel. Very floral finish with cocoa undertones.
desc_2: Produced by Juan Carlos Mejia of Finca La Secreta, entirely of the Caturra variety of Arabica, and processed by the anaerobic natural method with the addition of lychee to the fermentation. Bear Lake Coffee Co., a B Corp-certified coffeehouse and roastery located in Barronett, Wisconsin, is committed to sustainability through its Coffee with a Purpose™ initiative, which ensures that farmers receive compensation well above the Fairtrade Premium for their exceptional small-batch coffee. Visit www.bearlakecoffee.com for more information.
desc_3: Colombia Caturra co-fermented with Lychee for dramatic and delicious effect — think floral bomb carried by distinct lychee notes (and cocoa nib).

name: Colombia Lychee Co-Ferment

name: Marcela Gesha Espresso
desc_1: Evaluated as espresso. Co-taster John DiRuocco and Ken both found a sweetly tangy intrigue animating this plush, satiny bodied espresso, and rewarded it with 95s. Ken called it rich pistachio; John favored musky, mango-like tropical fruit. For both tasters, the pistachio/mango notes impressively sweetened and moved forward in three parts milk.
desc_2: Produced by Shady & Elias Bayter of El Vergel Estate, entirely of the Gesha variety of Arabica, and processed by the carbonic maceration natural method, which involves fermenting whole coffee fruit inside a sealed container that has been flushed with CO2, then drying the coffee in the whole fruit. Imported by Forest Coffee. Big Shoulders Coffee is a Chicago artisan roaster that emphasizes a fresh-roasted, no-nonsense approach to fine coffee. Visit www.bigshoulderscoffee.com or call 312-846-1439 for more information.
desc_3: Sweetness, balance and confidence in a carbonic-macerated Gesha with a musky, tangy originality. Explore Similar CoffeesClick here for more reviews from Big Shoulders CoffeeClick here for more information about coffees from ColombiaVisit Big Shoulders Coffee

name: Colombia Paraiso 92 Double Anaerobic
desc_1: Evaluated as espresso. Sweet grapefruit and orange blossom notes shimmer inside a deeply expressed chocolate in aroma and cup. Velvety mouthfeel. Ken and co-taster John DiRuocco shared parallel descriptors and the same 95-point enthusiasm for this poised, resonantly finishing espresso. Floral-toned chocolate with a continued grapefruit hint graces three parts milk.
desc_2: Produced by Wilton Benitez entirely of the Colombia variety of Arabica, and processed by the anaerobic kōji method, in which the coffee fruit is first sterilized and then fermented in a bio-reactor and inoculated with a selection of Japanese kōji (Aspergillus oryzae). This mold species breaks down starch into simple sugars and is commonly used in the production of soy sauce, miso, sake and shōchū. After this whole-fruit fermentation, skin and pulp are removed and the coffee is subjected to a second anaerobic fermentation. A bean-sealing process follows, carried out through successive impacts of hot and cold water, before the beans are dried by machine for 46 hours. Imported to Taiwan by Pebble Coffee. ​​Bargain Cafe is a specialty coffee roaster in Taitung, Taiwan. Visit www.bargain-cafe.com for more information.
desc_3: Chocolate is deep, nuanced and alive with sweet citrus and flowers in this espresso co-taster John DiRuocco called “elegant, round yet complex.”Explore Similar CoffeesClick here for more reviews from Bargain CafeVisit Bargain Cafe

name: Colombia Sierra Morena Pink Bourbon
desc_1: Evaluated as espresso. This was Ken’s favorite in the tasting; he had it at 96 with a 10 for aroma. Co-taster John DiRuocco was a bit less enthusiastic at 94. The difference may have been their reading of the striking floral herb notes. Ken experienced them as exhilarating sweet lavender while John read them as a pleasant but drier eucalyptus. But both overall admired this sweetly citrusy, walnut-toned, brightly chocolaty espresso whose character resonates through the finish and retains character impressively in three parts milk.
desc_2: Produced by Wilson Alva of Finca Sierra Morena, entirely of the Pink Bourbon variety of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin, pulp and flesh all removed before drying). Imported by Coffee Quest. Wonderstate Coffee, formerly Kickapoo Coffee, is an award-winning roaster based in rural Wisconsin known for its commitment to guaranteeing higher pay for farmers and operating the country’s first 100% solar-powered roastery. Visit www.wonderstate.com for more information.
desc_3: A deeply complex, gently citrusy, crisply floral espresso that rounds gracefully without losing character in cappuccino-scaled milk.

name: Ethiopia Growers Reserve Gesha Village Gaylee Special Fermentation
desc_1: Evaluated as espresso. Resonant, layered berry (blueberry, raspberry), vanilla-toned flowers, papaya, a hint of cinnamon jostle in aroma and in the cup, where aromatics are suspended in a layered structure of complex bitter, sweet, tart and savory tastes. Ken (94) liked this velvety, viscous espresso a bit better than co-taster John DiRuocco (93). The complexity consolidates a bit in three parts milk, where flavor settles in with quiet certainty around a pronounced chocolate.
desc_2: Produced from trees of the rare Ethiopia-derived botanical variety Gesha (also Geisha) by Adam and Rachel Overton. Although the Gesha variety originated in Ethiopia, it was “discovered” by the coffee world in 2004 growing in Boquete, Panama. This particular version, however, is the outcome of efforts to commercialize Gesha in the region from which it originally came. It was processed by a proprietary method described as “semi-anaerobic honey.” AOI Coffee is a specialty roaster and cafe in Taiping, Taichung, Taiwan. Visit facebook.com/AOICoffeeRoaster for more information.
desc_3: A particularly complex straight espresso with a substantial mouthfeel and shifting, layered structure and aroma.Explore Similar CoffeesClick here for more reviews from AOI CoffeeClick here for more information about coffees from Ethiopia

name: Ethiopia Anaerobic Washed G1 Wild Rose S.O. Sidamo
origin: Bensa District, Sidamo growing region, Ethiopia
desc_1: Evaluated as espresso. Ripe, berryish fruit hints at brandy in this lush yet tartly dry espresso that reveals its rounder chocolate side in the cup. Ken (93) decided to like its intensity and tart fruit sweetness. Co-cupper John DiRuocco went more decisively to the bright side at 94. Convincing in three parts milk: crisp chocolate with a juicy, fruit-toned finish.
desc_2: Produced by smallholding farmers, from local Ethiopian landrace varieties of Arabica, and processed by the anaerobic washed method, in which, after skin and pulp removal, fermentation takes place in a hermetically sealed vessel before the beans are washed and dried. Imported into Taiwan by Wells Coffee. Balmy Day Coffee Office is a specialty nano-roastery based in Taoyuan, Taiwan. For more information, visit facebook.com/Balmydaycoffee.
desc_3: If you enjoy tart, fruit-toned authority with an underlying sweet swoon, you will like this slightly edgy espresso as a straight shot. Once it gets into milk everyone will like it.Explore Similar CoffeesClick here for more reviews from Balmy Day Coffee OfficeClick here for more information about coffees from Ethiopia

name: Colombia Buenavista Ataraxia Geisha
desc_1: Evaluated as espresso. In the aroma, lush, chocolaty fruit (maraschino cherry, ripe orange) transforms to a bright, floral citrus in the cup, slightly drying but sweet. Co-taster John DiRuocco (94) felt that the entire package came together nicely, with “nice high notes balanced by chocolate undertones, acidity by body.” Ken had less conviction in regard to coherence, but he too characterized the mouthfeel as full and plush, the cup impressive, and seconded John’s 94. Both particularly praised the coffee in three parts milk, where lemon, chocolate and cherry tendencies played nicely.
desc_2: Produced at Finca Buenavista, entirely of the Geisha variety of Arabica, and processed by the double-anaerobic washed method, in which the whole coffee fruit is subjected to anaerobic fermentation, after which the skins and pulp are removed, the coffee is anaerobically fermented a second time, and washed before drying. Imported directly by Euphora Coffee. Euphora is a Taipei-based specialty coffee roaster with an active online community through which all sales are made. Visit www.euphoracoffeestudio.com for more information.
desc_3: A fine espresso for those who enjoy paradox: intense yet balanced; bright yet full.Explore Similar CoffeesClick here for more reviews from Euphora CoffeeClick here for more information about coffees from ColombiaVisit Euphora Coffee

desc_1: Evaluated as espresso. Ken (94) found this anaerobic natural Kona luxurious with deep floral notes and softly subtle chocolate and orange. Co-taster John DiRuocco (93) concurred but was bothered by what he regarded as a very slight overripe edge to the fruit. Both found the mouthfeel medium in weight but impressively plush in texture, and the shot in three parts milk delicately complex with flowers, fruit and chocolate working in layered coherence.
desc_2: A single-farm blend of coffees grown, processed and roasted at Hula Daddy. Processed by the anaerobic natural method, in which the whole fruit is fermented with limited oxygen before it is dried. Hula Daddy is a boutique coffee producer with farms at the 1,400- and 2,500-foot levels of the Mount Hualalai volcano near the northern end of the Kona growing district, five minutes above the town of Kailua-Kona. Visit www.huladaddy.com or call 808-327-9744 for more information.

name: Colombia El Diviso Nestor Lasso Sidra Anaerobic Washed
desc_1: Evaluated as espresso. Lots of flowers with an herby edge—lavender, jasmine, orange blossom, cilantro—cushion on milk chocolate in this bright, light-footed espresso. Both co-taster John DiRuocco and Ken read this high-toned but resonant espresso in about the same terms with parallel ratings of 94. Resolves to an orangy, floral caramel in three parts milk.
desc_2: Produced by Nestor Lasso of Finca El Diviso, entirely of the Sidra variety of Arabica, and processed by the anaerobic washed method, in which, after skin and pulp removal, fermentation takes place in a hermetically sealed vessel before the beans are washed and dried. OLI Cafe Roaster is a specialty coffee roaster based in Dali, Taichung, Taiwan. Visit www.facebook.com/OLI.caferoaster for more information.
desc_3: A fine anthology of herbs and flowers in this buoyant, animated espresso.Explore Similar CoffeesClick here for more reviews from OLI Cafe RoasterClick here for more information about coffees from Colombia

name: Colombia Red Fruits Campo Hermosa Edwin Noreña
desc_1: Evaluated as espresso. Co-taster John DiRuocco (95) was particularly impressed by the lavish sweetness and fruit of this elaborately anaerobic-processed coffee from Colombian processing innovator Edwin Noreña. John found the well-structured and clean-finishing character sufficient to contain and balance the aromatic fireworks. Ken (92), on the other hand, found the sweetness and fruit a bit too intense and candy-like, though he found compensating value in underlying musk and sandalwood tendencies. Both tasters admired the coffee in three parts milk, which rounded and diluted the intensely sweet fruit.
desc_2: Produced by Edwin Noreña of Finca Campo Hermosa, entirely of the Red Bourbon variety of Arabica, and processed by a complex version of carbonic maceration. Whole coffee fruit is soaked in water for four hours, then subject to carbonic maceration for 72 hours with coffee must or mossto (juice from compressed coffee fruit). After removal of skins and pulp (pulping), a second carbonic maceration with mossto, red fruits and wine yeast follows, after which the coffee is sun dried for about 25 days. Imported by Yellow Rooster. Royal Flamingo is a Columbus, Ohio-based specialty coffee roaster. Visit www.royalflamingocoffee.com for more information.
desc_3: If you like extravagant fruit grandeur (or if you are a coffee classicist looking for a fling), try this one.   Explore Similar CoffeesClick here for more reviews from Royal Flamingo CoffeeClick here for more information about coffees from Colombia

name: Juru Rwanda Rulindo Red Bourbon Honey

desc_1: Evaluated as espresso. Co-taster John DiRuocco (94) liked this coffee (“brightly orange and juicy, sweet, jasmine and stone fruit”) a bit better than Ken did (93), who nevertheless concurred with John’s descriptors and added dark chocolate and molasses. Both found the mouthfeel plush and satiny. In three parts milk, the shot proved delicate yet substantial, with an animated, light-footed chocolate.
desc_2: Produced by Juru Coffee at the Burega, Buyoga and Cyinzuzi farms, entirely of the Red Bourbon variety of Arabica, and processed by the honey method (skins and attached pulp are removed, but some fruit flesh is left on the beans during drying). Imported by Linking Coffee. MK Coffee Roasters, a short walk from the Shulin train station in New Taipei City, specializes in high-quality roasted beans to take home and expertly brewed coffees to enjoy in the café. Visit www.mkcoffee.com.tw or e-mail [email protected] for more information.

name: Colombia Granja Paraiso-92 Castillo
desc_1: Evaluated as espresso. Co-taster John DiRuocco (94) found spicy fruit, orange water and vanilla-like flowers in aroma and cup; Ken (93) concurred and added sweet chocolate and almonds. Altogether a silky textured, lively espresso. The aromatic intricacy consolidates a bit in three parts milk, and the familiar chocolate and almondy nut move forward.
desc_2: Produced by Wilton Benitez, entirely of the Castillo variety of Arabica, and processed by the double-anaerobic thermal shock method, in which the coffee fruit, after having been first sanitized with ozone, undergoes two stages of fermentation. First, the whole cherries are submerged under water for 48 hours, then the beans are pulped and fermented with a strain of Lactobacillus for 24 hours. After fermentation, the beans are given a “thermal shock” using hot and cold rinses to help the beans absorb the fermentation metabolites and halt any further fermentation. Paradise prides itself on quality and freshness, craft-roasting coffees in small batches only after orders are placed. Visit www.paradiseroasters.com or call 808-498-4048 for more information.

name: Colombia Paraiso 92 Geisha Double Anaerobic
desc_1: Nuanced, multi-layered fruit-forward. Bergamot, apricot nectar, star jasmine, lemon balm, sandalwood in aroma and cup. Complex, juicy acidity; full, syrupy mouthfeel. Long-lasting finish that carries over all the flavor notes from the cup.
desc_2: Produced by Wilton Benitez entirely of the Geisha variety of Arabica. Processed by the kōji method, in which the coffee fruit is first sterilized and then fermented in a bio-reactor and inoculated with a selection of Japanese kōji (Aspergillus oryzae). This mold species breaks down starch into simple sugars and is commonly used in the production of soy sauce, miso, sake and shōchū. After whole-fruit fermentation, the coffee is pulped and subjected to a second fermentation phase. desc_2: Produced by Wilton Benitez of Granja Paraiso 92, entirely of the Chiroso variety of Arabica, and processed by the thermal shock method, in which the coffee fruit, after having been first sanitized with ozone, undergoes two stages of fermentation. First, the whole cherries are submerged under water for 48 hours, then the beans are pulped and fermented with a strain of Lactobacillus for 24 hours. After fermentation, the beans are given a “thermal shock” using hot and cold rinses to help the beans absorb the fermentation metabolites and halt any further fermentation. Afterward, the washed parchment coffee is rapidly dried with an in-house designed Eco-Enigma dehumidifying dryer to avoid over-oxidation or continued fermentation. Big Shoulders Coffee is a Chicago artisan roaster that emphasizes a fresh-roasted, no-nonsense approach to fine coffee. Visit www.bigshoulderscoffee.com or call 312-846-1439 for more information.

name: Colombia Finca Milan Washed Nitro Caturra
desc_1: Delicately sweet, richly perfumed. Watermelon candy, lychee, magnolia, almond butter, black sage in aroma and cup. Balanced, bright acidity; very full, creamy mouthfeel. Resonant finish centers notes of watermelon candy, magnolia and almond.

Following bioreactor treatment, the coffee beans are solar-dried to 40% moisture, then transferred to mechanical dryers until they reach 10%-12% moisture. The coffee undergoes a 45-day resting period in the warehouse before hulling. Revel Coffee is a micro-roaster located in Billings, Montana. desc_1: Sweet-toned, crisply chocolaty. Baking chocolate, hazelnut, red apple, cedar, Meyer lemon zest in aroma and cup. Gentle, round acidity; lightly satiny, buoyant mouthfeel. Finish consolidates to notes of baking chocolate and hazelnut.
desc_2: Produced at Monarch Farm, entirely of the Kona Typica variety of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). The Hapa is a blend of three roast levels: light, medium and dark. Monarch Coffee is an award-winning coffee farm and specialty roaster of 100% estate-grown Kona coffee on the Big Island of Hawai’i. Visit www.monarchcoffee.com for more information.
desc_3: A pleasingly familiar Kona profile that’s a post-roast melange with top notes of citrus zest and depth from rich chocolate notes.Explore Similar CoffeesClick here for more reviews from Monarch CoffeeClick here for more information about coffees from HawaiiVisit Monarch Coffee

name: SL28 Honey
origin: North Kona growing district, “Big Island” of Hawai’i

desc_2: Produced at Hala Tree Farm entirely of the SL28 variety of Arabica and processed by the honey method, in which some of the fruit flesh is left on the beans during the drying process. Hala Tree Coffee is a family-owned coffee farm in the heart of the Kona coffee belt, overlooking historic Kealakekua Bay. The 100% Kona Coffee produced on this USDA organic-certified property is processed and roasted on site to ensure quality. For more information, visit www.halatreecoffee.com.

name: Wilton Benitez Geisha
desc_1: Brightly sweet-tart, floral-toned. Magnolia, ume plum, candycap mushroom, amber, lemon balm in aroma and cup. High-toned, juicy acidity; vibrant, silky mouthfeel. Exceptionally long, coherent finish.
desc_2: Produced by Wilton Benitez, entirely of the Geisha variety of Arabica, and processed by the double-anaerobic thermal shock method, in which the coffee fruit, after having been first sanitized with ozone, undergoes two stages of fermentation. First, the whole cherries are submerged under water for 48 hours, then the beans are pulped and fermented with a strain of Lactobacillus for 24 hours. After fermentation, the beans are given a “thermal shock” using hot and cold rinses to help the beans absorb the fermentation metabolites and halt any further fermentation. JBC Coffee Roasters’ vision is simple: “let the coffee lead the way” through sourcing and roasting the best and most unique coffees available and rewarding the farmers who grow those coffees with substantial premiums. Visit www.jbccoffeeroasters.com or call 608-256-5282 for more information.

Although the Gesha variety originated in Ethiopia, it was “discovered” by the coffee world in 2004 growing in Boquete, Panama, and Panama continues to dominate the expanding world of Gesha. name: Colombia El Paraiso Geisha Luna Washed
desc_1: Richly aromatic, chocolaty and fruit-forward. Dark chocolate, bergamot, lychee, musk, tarragon in aroma and cup. Juicy-bright acidity; plush, syrupy mouthfeel. Intense, quite long finish with leading notes of dark chocolate and tarragon.
desc_2: This exceptional coffee was selected as the No. 25 coffee on Coffee Review’s list of the Top 30 Coffees of 2023.  Produced by Wilton Benitez of Granja Paraiso 92, entirely of the Geisha variety of Arabica, and processed by the double-anaerobic thermal shock method, in which the coffee fruit, after having been first sanitized with ozone, undergoes two stages of fermentation. First, the whole cherries are submerged under water for 48 hours, then the beans are pulped and fermented with a strain of Lactobacillus for 24 hours. After fermentation, the beans are given a “thermal shock” using hot and cold rinses to help the beans absorb the fermentation metabolites and halt any further fermentation. Afterward, the washed parchment coffee is rapidly dried with an in-house designed Eco-Enigma dehumidifying dryer to avoid over-oxidation or continued fermentation. SÖT Coffee Roaster, based in Osaka, Japan, is a self-described Swedish-style roaster with an “aggressively light” roasting style. For more information, visit www.sotcoffee.com.
desc_3: A focused, intensely perfumed, experimentally processed Colombia Geisha that’s, at turns, chocolaty, musky, tropical and sweetly herbaceous.Explore Similar CoffeesClick here for more reviews from SOT Coffee RoasterClick here for more information about coffees from ColombiaVisit SOT Coffee Roaster

name: Kona Pointu®
origin: Holualoa, North Kona growing district, “Big Island” of Hawai’i
desc_1: Lively, aromatically resonant, deeply complex. Cocoa nib, vanilla orchid, tamarind, pistachio, amber in aroma and cup. Rich structure with sweet-tart-savory acidity; lyrically full, viscous body. Harmonious, integrated finish that leads with notes of vanilla orchid, pistachio and cocoa nib.
desc_2: This exceptional coffee was selected as the No. 2 coffee on Coffee Review’s list of the Top 30 Coffees of 2023. Bourbon Pointu, botanical name var. Laurina, is a natural mutation of the famous Bourbon variety, first selected on Reunion Island in the Indian Ocean. The Bourbon Pointu is famous for its naturally low levels of caffeine, bean shape (small and tending to be pointed at the ends, hence “pointu”), and pungently fruit-toned, Bourbon-like cup. This version was produced in Kona and is a natural-processed coffee (dried in the whole fruit). Hula Daddy is a boutique coffee producer with farms at the 1,400 and 2,500 foot levels of the Mount Hualalai volcano near the northern end of the Kona growing district, five minutes above the town of Kailua-Kona. Visit www.huladaddy.com or call 888-553-2339 for more information.
desc_3: A vibrantly aromatic, enigmatically complex Kona Pointu Laurina, a rare coffee presented with farming, processing and roasting precision, resulting in fireworks in the cup.Explore Similar CoffeesClick here for more reviews from Hula Daddy Kona CoffeeClick here for more information about coffees from HawaiiVisit Hula Daddy Kona Coffee

name: Colombia Calderon Honey

Produced by Luis Calderon of Finca Betulia, from trees of the Castillo, Colombia and Red Bourbon variety of Arabica, and processed by the double-anaerobic honey method, in which ripe cherries undergo a meticulous fermentation process in oxygen-free bags for 24-48 hours. Then the fruit skin is removed and the beans are fermented again for an additional 48 hours in closed containers. The beans then undergo precise mechanical drying, with careful attention paid to controlling Brix degrees, temperature, and pH levels. Revel Coffee is a micro-roaster located in Billings, Montana. Its motto: “Quality is paramount – a difference you can revel in.” Visit www.revelcoffee.com or call 406-534-9621 for more information.

name: Wilton Benitez Colombia Sidra
desc_1: Elegantly floral, vibrantly fruit-forward. Wisteria, bergamot, frankincense, mangosteen, black cherry in aroma and cup. Juicy, high-toned acidity; plush, creamy mouthfeel. Long, lingering, flavor-saturated finish.
desc_2: This exceptional coffee was selected as the No. 4 coffee on Coffee Review’s list of the Top 30 Coffees of 2023. Produced by Wilton Benitez of Granja Paraiso 92, entirely of the Sidra variety of Arabica, and processed by the double-anaerobic thermal shock method, in which the coffee fruit, after having been first sanitized with ozone, undergoes two stages of fermentation. First, the whole cherries are submerged under water for 48 hours, then the beans are pulped and fermented with a strain of Lactobacillus for 24 hours. After fermentation, the beans are given a “thermal shock” using hot and cold rinses to help the beans absorb the fermentation metabolites and halt any further fermentation. Afterward, the washed parchment coffee is rapidly dried with an in-house designed Eco-Enigma dehumidifying dryer to avoid over-oxidation or continued fermentation. Founded in 2013, modcup coffee focuses on fresh roasting and distinctive natural-processed coffees. Visit modcup.com for more information.

name: Colombia Wilton Benitez Thermal Shock Geisha
desc_1: Richly tropical, sweetly herbaceous. Pineapple, passionfruit, lemon verbena, ginger blossom, toffee in aroma and cup. Sparkling acidity; plush, silky mouthfeel. Long, lingering harmonious finish.
desc_2: This exceptional coffee was selected as the No. 13 coffee on Coffee Review’s list of the Top 30 Coffees of 2023. Produced by Wilton Benitez of Granja Paraiso 92, entirely of the Geisha variety of Arabica, and processed by the thermal shock method, in which the coffee fruit, after having been first sanitized with ozone, undergoes two stages of fermentation. First, the whole cherries are submerged under water for 48 hours, then the beans are pulped and fermented with a strain of Lactobacillus for 24 hours. After fermentation, the beans are given a “thermal shock” using hot and cold rinses to help the beans absorb the fermentation metabolites and halt any further fermentation. Afterward, the washed parchment coffee is rapidly dried with an in-house designed Eco-Enigma dehumidifying dryer to avoid over-oxidation or continued fermentation.Big Shoulders Coffee is a Chicago artisan roaster that emphasizes a fresh-roasted, no-nonsense approach to fine coffee. Visit www.bigshoulderscoffee.com or call 312-846-1439 for more information.

name: Colombia Cauca Finca El Paraiso Double Anaerobic Flor Lichi
desc_1: Tropical fruit-toned. Mango, orange zest, dark chocolate, marjoram, oak in aroma and cup. Very sweet structure with brisk acidity; plush, syrupy mouthfeel. Chocolaty, fruity finish.
desc_2: Produced by Diego Bermudez of Finca al Paraiso, from trees of the Castillo, Colombia and Caturra varieties of Arabica, and processed by the double-anaerobi washed method, in which the coffee fruit, after having been first sanitized with ozone, undergoes two stages of fermentation. First, the whole cherries are submerged under water for 48 hours, then the beans are pulped and fermented with a strain of Lactobacillus for 24 hours. After fermentation, the beans are given a “thermal shock” using hot and cold rinses to help the beans absorb the fermentation metabolites and halt any further fermentation. Afterward, the washed parchment coffee is rapidly dried with an in-house designed Eco-Enigma dehumidifying dryer to avoid over-oxidation or continued fermentation. Lee Dong Coffee is a specialty coffee roaster and cafe in Taichung, Taiwan. Visit www.facebook.com/LiDongcoffee/ for more information.

name: Colombia Chili Bourbon
desc_1: Sweetly spice-toned, uniquely composed. Szechuan peppercorn, lemon balm, dark chocolate, lavender, date in aroma and cup. Winy acidity; crisp, syrupy mouthful. Chocolaty, spice-toned finish.
desc_2: Produced by Edwin Noreña of Finca Campo Hermoso, entirely of the Bourbon variety of Arabica, and processed by the carbonic maceration method, as follows: The whole fruit is co-fermented with aji chili must in oxygen-free containers for 96 hours. The fruit is then semi-washed (some of the fruit flesh is left on the bean), then returned to the carbonic fermentation tanks and re-infused with fresh aji chili must for an additional 48 hours. After the secondary carbonic fermentation, the coffee is dried on raised beds for 22 days and then set in a relative humidity-controlled warehouse for a final eight days of repose. Barrington Coffee is an artisan roaster dedicated to elite coffees, fresh delivery, and roasting that foregrounds the coffee and not the roast. name: Colombia Finca El Paraíso Geisha Sake

desc_2: This exceptional coffee was selected as the No. 10 coffee on Coffee Review’s list of the Top 30 Coffees of 2023. Produced by Diego Bermudez, from trees of the original Panama T.2722 cultivar of the Geisha variety of Arabica, and processed by the double-anaerobic washed method, in which the coffee fruit, after having been first sanitized with ozone, undergoes two stages of fermentation. First, the whole cherries are submerged under water for 48 hours, then the beans are pulped and fermented with a strain of Lactobacillus for 24 hours. After fermentation, the beans are given a “thermal shock” using hot and cold rinses to help the beans absorb the fermentation metabolites and halt any further fermentation. Afterward, the washed parchment coffee is rapidly dried with an in-house designed Eco-Enigma dehumidifying dryer to avoid over oxidation or continued fermentation. Paradise prides itself on quality and freshness, craft-roasting coffees in small batches only after orders are placed. Visit paradiseroasters.com or call 763-433-0626 for more information.

desc_2: Produced by smallholding farmers, entirely of the Ethiopia 74110 variety of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). name: Wilton Benitez Pink Bourbon Colombia
desc_1: Wildly expressive, richly compelling. Blackberry jam, sweet cream, frankincense, honeysuckle, dried pineapple in aroma and cup. Wine-like, very juicy, integrated acidity; plush, syrupy mouthfeel. Very long, very complex finish that leads with notes of wild blackberry and frankincense.
desc_2: This remarking coffee was selected as the No. 1 coffee on Coffee Review’s list of the Top 30 Coffees of 2023. Produced by Wilton Benitez of La Macarena Farm, entirely of the Pink Bourbon variety of Arabica, and processed by a complexly detailed version of the double-anaerobic method (sealed-tank fermentation of the whole fruit with the addition of yeast stains), which includes sterilizing the cherries with ozone gas and ultraviolet light. JBC Coffee Roasters’ vision is simple: “let the coffee lead the way” through sourcing and roasting the best and most unique coffees available and rewarding the farmers who grow those coffees with substantial premiums. Visit www.jbccoffeeroasters.com or call 608-256-5282 for more information.

JBC Coffee Roasters’ vision is simple: “let the coffee lead the way” through sourcing and roasting the best and most unique coffees available and rewarding the farmers who grow those coffees with substantial premiums. name: Rose Fruit Dew B40
desc_1: Raspberry jam, toffee, dark chocolate, lilac, hint of teriyaki sauce in aroma and cup. Sweetly tart structure with brisk acidity; plush, syrupy mouthfeel. Savory-leaning in the resonant finish with notes of teriyaki sauce supported by dark chocolate.
desc_2: Produced by Wilton Benitez of Finca El Paraíso entirely of the rare Pink Bourbon variety of Arabica, and processed by a complexly detailed version of the double-anaerobic method (sealed-tank fermentation of the whole fruit with the addition of brewer’s yeast, removal of skin and pulp, and a second fermentation of the beans shut in the tank with the removed skin and pulp). Additional processing nuance includes a thermal shock wash (soaking the whole fruit in hot water for 30 seconds, then cold water for 30 seconds) to reduce astringency. Green Stone Coffee is a woman-owned artisan roastery in Taipei, Taiwan founded in 2016 and specializing in sourcing distinctive coffees that express their individual terroirs. Visit www.greenstone-coffee.com.tw for more information.
desc_3: A richly sweet experimentally processed Colombia cup with floral and umami undercurrents throughout (think lilac and teriyaki in strange harmony).Explore Similar CoffeesClick here for more reviews from Green Stone CoffeeClick here for more information about coffees from Colombia

name: Ethiopia Lucy Geisha
desc_1: Richly sweet, gently tart. Wisteria, pomegranate, fresh-cut fir, brown sugar, grapefruit zest in aroma and cup. Brisk acidity; very full, satiny mouthfeel. The finish consolidates to notes of fir, brown sugar and grapefruit zest.
desc_2: Produced from trees of the rare Ethiopia-derived botanical variety Gesha (also Geisha) by Adam and Rachel Overton. With its generally elongated beans and distinctive floral and crisp, often chocolaty cup, the Gesha variety continues to distinguish itself as one of the world’s most unique coffees. Although the Gesha variety originated in Ethiopia, it was “discovered” by the coffee world in 2004 growing in Boquete, Panama, and Panama continues to dominate the expanding world of Gesha. This particular version, however, is the outcome of efforts to commercialize Gesha in the region from which it originally came. It is processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). VERYTIME is a specialty nano-roaster based in Taoyuan, Taiwan. Visit www.verytime.com.tw/ for more information.

desc_2: The first coffee from West Papua ever to be exported to North America or Europe. name: Costa Rica Turrialba Volcano Honey Process
desc_1: Fruit-toned, deeply sweet-tart. Blackberry, brown sugar, dark chocolate, cedar, star jasmine in aroma and cup. Bright and juicy with lively acidity; crisp, syrupy mouthfeel. Fruit-toned finish with undertones of brown sugar and cedar.

name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Adame Washed Process

name: Ethiopia Bench-Maji Lucy Station Geisha

desc_2: Produced from trees of the rare Ethiopia-derived botanical variety Gesha (also Geisha) by Adam and Rachel Overton. With its generally elongated beans and distinctive floral and crisp, often chocolaty cup, the Gesha variety continues to distinguish itself as one of the world’s most unique coffees. Although the Gesha variety originated in Ethiopia, it was “discovered” by the coffee world in 2004 growing in Boquete, Panama, and Panama continues to dominate the expanding world of Gesha. This particular version, however, is the outcome of efforts to commercialize Gesha in the region from which it originally came. name: Galaxy Gesha Quindio Colombia Edwin Noreña
desc_1: Soaringly high-toned anaerobic, bright, complex, exhilarating. Raspberry, rose, violet, cardamom, passionfruit in aroma and cup. In structure, layered and intriguingly savory-bright. Silky in mouthfeel, nimble and lively on the palate. Flowers carry far into a deep, long finish.

The skin and pulp are infused with Galaxy hops and recombined with the pulped beans in the carbonic fermentation tanks for another 96 hours before the beans are sun-dried on raised beds. name: Colombia Finca El Paraiso Rose Tea
desc_1: Subtly intense anaerobic flower bomb. Sweetly tangy, very brightly floral. Rose, yogurt, blood orange, peach, cashew butter in aroma and cup. Juicy and sweet-tart in structure; full, syrupy mouthfeel. Flowers lead in a balanced finish.

Processed by the kōji method, in which the coffee fruit is first sterilized and then fermented in a bio-reactor and inoculated with a selection of Japanese kōji (Aspergillus oryzae). This mold species breaks down starch into simple sugars and is commonly used in the production of soy sauce, miso, sake and shōchū. After whole-fruit fermentation, the coffee is pulped and subjected to a second fermentation phase. name: Colombia Pink Bourbon

desc_1: Quietly sweet, nut-toned. Hazelnut, cocoa powder, golden raisin, cedar, a hint of gardenia in aroma and cup. Sweet structure with gentle, round acidity; plush, satiny mouthfeel. The crisply sweet finish leads with notes of cocoa powder and hazelnut.
desc_2: A blend of Santos #2-grade coffees from a mixture of local varieties of Arabica,  processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). name: Colombia Don Correa Gesha

desc_2: Produced by José Giraldo and Jorge Correa of Finca San Juan entirely of the Geisha variety of Arabica, and processed by the natural carbonic maceration method, which involves fermenting whole coffee fruit inside a sealed container that has been flushed with CO2, then drying the coffee, still in the whole fruit. Founded in 1990, Roadmap CoffeeWorks, formerly Lexington Coffee Roasters, is an award-winning artisan roasting company based in Lexington, Virginia. name: Narsha Gesha
desc_1: Richly fruit-toned, cocoa-driven. Bing cherry, lychee, tangerine, cocoa nib, magnolia in aroma and cup. Very sweet, gently tart structure with juicy acidity; plush, viscous mouthfeel. Resonantly integrated, fruity and cocoa-toned finish.
desc_2: This exceptional coffee was selected as the No. 14 coffee on Coffee Review’s list of the Top 30 Coffees of 2022. Produced from trees of the rare Ethiopia-derived botanical variety Gesha (also spelled Geisha) by Adam and Rachel Overton. With its generally elongated beans and distinctive floral and crisp, often chocolaty cup, the Gesha variety continues to distinguish itself as one of the world’s most unique coffees. Although the Gesha variety originated in Ethiopia, it was “discovered” by the coffee world in 2004 growing in Boquete, Panama, and Panama continues to dominate the expanding world of Gesha. This particular version, however, is the outcome of efforts to commercialize Gesha in the region from which it originally came. It is processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). Corvus particularly focuses on processing methods and selective harvesting, which results in small, seasonal micro-lots of uniquely sweet, vibrant, and clean flavor profiles. For more information, visit www.corvuscoffee.com.

name: Colombia Castillo Fruit Maceration Series (Passionfruit)
desc_1: Powerfully aromatic, fruit-centered. Passionfruit, lychee, ginger flower, almond brittle, kumquat in aroma and cup. Sweet-tart structure with apple-toned, malic acidity; full, syrupy mouthfeel. Exceptionally harmonious and integrated finish into the far long.
desc_2: Produced by Jairo Arcila and Cofinet of Finca Santa Monica entirely of the Castillo variety of Arabica, and processed by an experimental fruit maceration process in which the whole fruit is first fermented in an anaerobic (limited oxygen) environment with wine yeasts and macerated fruit. After fermentation, the coffee cherries are pulped and placed to dry on raised beds with macerated fruits until the ideal moisture content is achieved. Founded in 2013, modcup coffee focuses on fresh roasting and distinctive natural-processed coffees. Visit modcup.com for more information.
desc_3: High-toned, explicitly and cleanly fruit-forward, leading with notes of passionfruit and lychee — tropics in a cup.

After fermentation, the coffee cherries are pulped and placed to dry on raised beds with macerated fruits until the ideal moisture content is achieved. After fermentation, the coffee cherries are pulped and placed to dry on raised beds with macerated fruits until the ideal moisture content is achieved. name: Balearic Beans

name: Costa Rica Las Lajas Perla Negra

desc_1: Delicately fruit-toned, richly tart. Raspberry jam, cocoa nib, lime, honeysuckle, cedar in aroma and cup. Sweetly tart structure with juicy acidity; syrupy-smooth mouthfeel. The finish consolidates to pleasing berry and citrus notes supported by cocoa nib.

name: Ecuador COE 1st place Arashi Typica Mejorado Washed

desc_2: Southern Ethiopia coffees like this one are largely produced from distinctive landrace Ethiopian varieties of Arabica long grown in the region. name: Ethiopia Bench Maji Gesha Village Dimma Illubabor Forest A6 Natural
desc_1: Gently fruit-toned, lyrically sweet. Nectarine, cherry blossom, almond butter, oregano, honey in aroma and cup. Richly sweet with high-toned acidity; full, syrupy mouthfeel. Integrated finish that retains all the notes from the aroma and cup.
desc_2: Produced from trees of the rare Ethiopia-derived botanical variety Gesha (also Geisha) by Adam and Rachel Overton. With its generally elongated beans and distinctive floral and crisp, often chocolaty cup, the Gesha variety continues to distinguish itself as one of the world’s most unique coffees. Although the Gesha variety originated in Ethiopia, it was “discovered” by the coffee world in 2004 growing in Boquete, Panama, and Panama continues to dominate the expanding world of Gesha. This particular version, however, is the outcome of efforts to commercialize Gesha in the region from which it originally came. It is processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). Taster’s Coffee is a nano-roaster based in new Taipei City, Taiwan. Visit www.tasterscoffee.com for more information.

name: Ethiopia Bench Maji Gesha Village Oma Geisha 1931 Lot 55 Natural
desc_1: Delicate, richly sweet, floral-toned. Star jasmine, raspberry, cocoa nib, maple syrup, sandalwood in aroma and cup. Bright, sweet-tart structure with juicy acidity; plush, satiny mouthfeel. The long finish centers around deep floral and bright berry tones, grounded by cocoa nib.
desc_2: Produced from trees of the rare Ethiopia-derived botanical variety Gesha (also Geisha) by Adam and Rachel Overton. With its generally elongated beans and distinctive floral and crisp, often chocolaty cup, the Gesha variety continues to distinguish itself as one of the world’s most unique coffees. Although the Gesha variety originated in Ethiopia, it was “discovered” by the coffee world in 2004 growing in Boquete, Panama, and Panama continues to dominate the expanding world of Gesha. This particular version, however, is the outcome of efforts to commercialize Gesha in the region from which it originally came. It is processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). Taster’s Coffee is a nano-roaster based in new Taipei City, Taiwan. Visit www.tasterscoffee.com for more information.

desc_1: Richly aromatic, complex, multi-layered. Lychee, lavender, cocoa nib, hazelnut butter, lemon-thyme in aroma and cup. Sweet-savory with lively, juicy acidity; plush, very syrupy mouthfeel. Long, resonant, flavor-saturated finish.
desc_2: This exceptional coffee was selected as the No. 24 coffee on Coffee Review’s list of the Top 30 Coffees of 2021.This 100% Kona coffee was produced from trees of the giant-beaned Maragogype variety of Arabica and processed by the natural method (beans are dried in the whole fruit). This sample consists entirely of peaberries, a kind of bean that results when the coffee fruit develops only a single, oval bean rather than the usual pair of flat-sided beans. Visit www.rustyshawaiian.com or call 808-928-8916 for more information.
desc_3: This very rare bean, a peaberry grade of the enormous Maragogype variety, produces here a gorgeous, vivid, richly sweet-savory cup.Explore Similar CoffeesClick here for more reviews from Rusty’s HawaiianClick here for more information about coffees from HawaiiVisit Rusty’s Hawaiian

name: Ecuador San José de Minas Double-Anaerobic
desc_1: Delicately sweet, richly perfumy. Bergamot, marzipan, lilac, apricot, cocoa nib in aroma and cup. Sweetly tart in structure with very lively, juicy acidity; lightly viscous, silky mouthfeel. The finish centers around notes of bergamot and lily, rounding to cocoa nib in the long.
desc_2: Produced by Galo Morales of Finca Cruz Loma, of the Sidra and Typica Mejorada varieties of Arabica, and processed by the anaerobic washed method. Peach Coffee Roasters is an Atlanta, Georgia-based specialty roaster. Visit peachcoffeeroasters.com for more information.
desc_3: A resonant, clean, vibrantly sweet-tart washed anaerobic Ecuador cup with an exhilaratingly complex range of aromatic expression.Explore Similar CoffeesClick here for more reviews from Peach Coffee RoastersClick here for more information about coffees from Ecuador

desc_2: Produced by Andres Guaca of Finca La Bandida entirely of the rare Pink Bourbon variety of Arabica, and processed by fermenting whole cherries for 65 hours with the addition of lactobacilli, then drying them in the sun. desc_3: A richly bittersweet Colombia cup processed with the addition of lactobacilli to the whole-cherry fermentation, resulting in a fundamentally sweet cup with savory undertones.Explore Similar CoffeesClick here for more reviews from Peach Coffee RoastersClick here for more information about coffees from Colombia

name: Congo Square
origin: South Kivu growing region, Democratic Republic of the Congo
desc_1: High-toned, resinously nutty, intensely sweet. Wild honey, plum, magnolia, mesquite, pistachio in aroma and cup. Sweet-tart structure with savory-leaning acidity; viscous, nectar-like mouthfeel. Gentle, sweetly rich finish with notes of wild honey, pistachio and mesquite into the long.
desc_2: This exceptional coffee was selected as the No. 21 coffee on Coffee Review’s list of the Top 30 Coffees of 2021. This coffee tied for the highest rating in a cupping of African Great Lakes coffees for Coffee Review’s June 2021 report. Certified fair trade and USDA Organic. Named for the birthplace of jazz, Congo Square, in New Orleans. Produced by smallholding farmers entirely of local strains of the Bourbon variety of Arabica and processed by the washed method (fruit skin and flesh are removed from the beans before they are dried). Imported by Mighty Peace, a social enterprise organization that supports the Congolese coffee-farming community. Founded in 2019, Three Keys is a craft coffee roastery in Houston, Texas. The company name is inspired by the valves of the trumpet, which has been the instrument of choice for some of the most influential jazz musicians and composers. Three Keys says its coffees “speak a language that’s sophisticated yet accessible to everyone who’s willing to slow down and share a cup.” Visit www.threekeyscoffee.com for more information.

name: Original Gold Coffee Pouches
desc_1: Evaluated at a steeping time of 6 minutes. This beverage is composed of coffee that has essentially been toasted but not roasted. Toasted grain, cocoa nib, hints of raw cashew and limelike citrus in aroma and cup. Sweet, woody/grainy structure with a hint of bitterness but no acidy sensation whatsoever. desc_2: The Golden Ratio company aims at selling North America on a coffee produced by steeping plump bags of ground coffee that has essentially been toasted rather than roasted. Instructions accompanying these pouches suggest steeping the pouch 5 to 10 minutes to produce an 8-ounce beverage. We achieved what we considered optimal results (maximum aromatic interest) at around 6 minutes. The pouches also can be brewed at room temperature for a recommended 12 to 18 hours. For more information go to drinkgoldenratio.com.

The coffee earned the highest rating in a cupping of coffees from roasters in North American beach and coastal communities for Coffee Review’s April 2021 report. Mocca (also spelled Moka and Mokka) is a rare variety of Arabica that apparently originated in the Reunion Islands as a mutant of the great Bourbon variety. This Mocca was processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). This unusual coffee with its tiny beans and striking cup is available only on the Hula Daddy website through their allocation list. Hula Daddy is a boutique coffee producer with farms at the 1,400- and 2,500-foot levels of the Mount Hualalai volcano near the northern end of the Kona growing district, five minutes above the town of Kailua-Kona. This coffee was produced at the higher elevation Hula Daddy farm. Visit www.huladaddy.com or call 888-553-2339 for more information.

name: Kona Peaberry
origin: Kona growing region, Big Island of Hawai’i
desc_1: Balanced, deep-toned, floral. Honeysuckle, apricot, almond butter, dark chocolate, a hint of thyme in aroma and cup. Sweet structure with comfortable, straightforward acidity; plush, viscous mouthfeel. Floral-driven finish with undertones of dark chocolate and almond.

Produced at Kona Hills Farm entirely of the Typica variety of Arabica and processed by the washed method (fruit skin and flesh are removed from the beans before they are dried). Consists entirely of peaberries, a kind of bean that results when the coffee fruit develops only a single, oval bean rather than the usual pair of flat-sided beans.  Peaberries produce a somewhat different (often better) cup than normal beans from the same crop, from which they may or may not be separated during grading. Big Island Coffee is an award-winning coffee roaster operated with hands-on passion by Kelleigh Stewart and Brandon von Damitz. Visit www.bigislandcoffeeroasters.com for more information.

name: Bourbon Pointu Natural
origin: Kona growing region, Big Island of Hawai’i

desc_2: This coffee tied for the third-highest rating in a cupping of coffees from roasters in North American beach and coastal communities for Coffee Review’s April 2021 report. Bourbon Pointu, botanical name var. Laurina, is a natural mutation of the famous Bourbon variety, first selected on Reunion Island in the Indian Ocean. The Bourbon Pointu is famous for its natural low levels of caffeine, bean shape (small and tending to be pointed at the ends, hence “pointu”), and pungently fruit-toned, Bourbon-like cup. This version was grown in Kona and processed by the natural method (beans are dried in the whole fruit). Kraig and Leslie Lee have been growing and harvesting traditional Kona Coffee for over 25 years. In 2017 they introduced several distinguished new tree varieties to their 4.7 acre farm. The Formosa Coffee is a New York-based roaster specializing exclusively in high-quality coffees grown in Taiwan. For more information, visit www.theformosacoffee.com.
desc_3: A crisp, cleanly fruit-toned Taiwan cup presented by a New York roaster specializing in coffees from the island of Taiwan. A good resource for North Americans who want to sample the production end of the exuberant Taiwanese coffee scene.Explore Similar CoffeesClick here for more reviews from The Formosa Coffee

name: Thailand Doi Pangkhon Dark Roast
desc_1: Crisply tart, chocolaty. Lime zest, dried apricot, chocolate fudge, agave syrup, cedar in aroma and cup. Sweet-toned structure with gentle, round acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. The deep finish is richly drying, very chocolaty.
desc_2: Doi Pangkhon is an emerging growing district in the Golden Triangle region of northern Thailand. This Arabica coffee from classic cultivars was processed by a particularly meticulous version of the wet or “washed” method, in which skin and fruit flesh are removed from the beans or seeds before they are dried. It was roasted in a style intended for both espresso and non-espresso brewing methods. Paradise Roasters specializes in micro-lot Arabica and Robusta coffees from Asia and other emerging origins. The company prides itself on quality and freshness, craft-roasting coffees in small batches only after orders are placed. Visit www.paradiseroasters.com or call 763-433-0626 for more information.
desc_3: A balanced, richly darker-roasted coffee from Thailand’s burgeoning Doi Pangkhon growing region — sweet, chocolaty, and enlivened by notes of citrus zest. Explore Similar CoffeesClick here for more reviews from Paradise RoastersVisit Paradise Roasters

name: Ethiopia Reko Yirgacheffe
desc_1: Richly sweet, deeply aromatic, floral-toned. Plum, Meyer lemon zest, tea rose, sandalwood, maple syrup in aroma and cup. Balanced, sweetly tart structure; smooth, syrupy mouthfeel. Notes of tea rose and sandalwood permeate the rich finish.
desc_2: Produced by the Reko Farming Cooperative from indigenous tree varieties long grown in the region and processed by the washed method (fruit skin and pulp are removed before drying). Committed to sourcing, roasting and brewing the finest coffees, Temple features coffee from distinguished single estates and cooperatives around the world. Visit www.templecoffee.com or call 916-454-1282 for more information.
desc_3: A harmoniously composed washed Ethiopia coffee with stone fruit and spice-toned floral notes at its heart.Explore Similar CoffeesClick here for more reviews from Temple Coffee RoastersClick here for more information about coffees from EthiopiaVisit Temple Coffee Roasters

name: Colombia Asobombo Inza
desc_1: High-toned, crisply sweet-tart. Concord grape, rhododendron, cocoa nib, sandalwood, maple syrup in aroma and cup. Brightly sweet structure with tart, juicy acidity; very plush, syrupy mouthfeel. The resonant finish consolidates to notes of cocoa nib and maple syrup with undertones of Concord grape.
desc_2: Produced by Asobombo, a group of small producers in the municipality of Inza Cauca, Colombia, from trees of the Caturra and Castillo varieties of Arabica, and processed by the washed method. Flight Coffee Co. is a coffee-loving, quality-focused roasting company based in Bedford, New Hampshire. Visit www.flightcoffeeco.com or call 603-836-6228 for more information.
desc_3: A beautifully structured, elegantly bright Colombia coffee with lush mouthfeel and deep aromatics.Explore Similar CoffeesClick here for more reviews from Flight Coffee Co.Click here for more information about coffees from Colombia

name: Ethiopia Sidamo Natural Twakok G1
origin: Sidamo (also Sidama) growing region, south-central Ethiopia
desc_1: Evaluated as espresso. Bright, juicy, sweetly tart. Pomegranate, hazelnut, cedar, freesia-like flowers, molasses in aroma and small cup. Syrupy-smooth mouthfeel; crisp, gently drying finish. Rounder and more nut-toned in three parts milk.
desc_2: Southern Ethiopia coffees like this one are largely produced from distinctive indigenous Ethiopian varieties of Arabica long grown in their respective regions. This is a dry-processed or “natural” version, meaning the beans were dried inside the fruit rather than after the fruit has been removed, as is the case with wet-processed or “washed” coffees. Bona Kafo is a Taiwan-based specialty coffee roaster. Visit www.bonakaforoastery.com.
desc_3: A tale of two coffees: The straight shot is bracingly tart-leaning, while the milk shot is gentler and more nut-toned. Both display attractive aspects of this natural-processed single-origin espresso.Explore Similar CoffeesClick here for more reviews from Bona Kafo RoasteryClick here for more information about coffees from Ethiopia

name: Panama Boquete Torre Lot #1 Geisha Honey
desc_1: Sweetly floral and spice-toned, delicate. Lilac, myrrh, cocoa nib, pink peppercorn, honey in aroma and cup. Balanced, sweetly tart structure with delicately vibrant acidity; very full, syrupy mouthfeel. Cocoa- and floral-toned finish.
desc_2: Produced from the trees of the rare Ethiopia-derived botanical variety Geisha (also spelled Gesha) by the Lamastus family at Elida Estate. With its generally elongated beans and distinctive floral and crisp, often chocolaty cup, the Geisha/Gesha variety continues to distinguish itself as one of the world’s most unique coffees. Processed by the honey method, in which some fruit flesh (“honey”) is allowed to adhere to the beans during drying. Bona Kafo is a Taiwan-based specialty coffee roaster. Visit www.bonakaforoastery.com.
desc_3: A sweetly subtle, nuanced Geisha cup processed by the honey method at Panama’s famed Elida Estate. Explore Similar CoffeesClick here for more reviews from Bona Kafo RoasteryClick here for more information about coffees from Panama

name: Honduras Buenos Aires
desc_1: Richly bittersweet, nut-toned. Caramelized hazelnut, cocoa nib, dried date, freesia-like flowers, fresh-cut fir in aroma and cup. Bittersweet structure with brisk acidity; full, lightly syrupy mouthfeel. The richly drying finish foregrounds caramelized hazelnut and cocoa-toned date.
desc_2: Produced at Finca Buenos Aires in Honduras from trees of the Catimor, Lempira and IHCAFE 90 varieties of Arabica and processed by the washed method. Committed to sourcing, roasting and brewing the finest coffees, Temple features coffee from distinguished single estates and cooperatives around the world. desc_3: A deep-toned Honduras cup with a throughline of cocoa, dried fruit, and crisp nut notes.Explore Similar CoffeesClick here for more reviews from Temple Coffee RoastersClick here for more information about coffees from HondurasVisit Temple Coffee Roasters

name: Nicaragua El Poste Pacamara
desc_1: Delicate, citrusy and nut-toned. Orange zest, almond, magnolia, date, baking chocolate in aroma and cup. Sweet structure with brisk acidity; velvety-smooth mouthfeel. Nut-framed finish supported by notes of orange zest and baking chocolate.
desc_2: Produced at Nicaragua’s Finca Le Poste entirely from trees of the big-beaned Pacamara variety of Arabica and processed by the washed method. name: Yellow Caturra (special lot)
origin: Ka’u growing region, Big island of Hawai’i
desc_1: Balanced, rich-toned, deeply sweet. Strawberry-guava, cocoa nib, narcissus, almond butter, fresh-cut oak in aroma and cup. Sweet in structure with appealing savory undertones and juicy acidity; very full, syrupy mouthfeel. Finish consolidates to cocoa-toned guava supported by hints of narcissus.
desc_2: Produced at Miranda Farms entirely of the Yellow Caturra variety of Arabica and processed by the washed method using anaerobic (limited oxygen) fermentation inoculated with wine yeast.  This is a special lot of Yellow Caturra coffee is sold only on the Big Island, distinct from Miranda's Farms other Yellow Caturra offerings listed on the company's website.  Miranda farms is a passionate, family-owned farm that puts great care into every step of the coffee production process to produce award-winning Hawaiian coffee. Visit https://mirandasfarms.com/ for more information.
desc_3: A resonant, confident alternative-processed Ka’u cup with pretty notes of tropical fruit and cocoa nib and an especially vibrant, lively structure.Explore Similar CoffeesClick here for more reviews from Miranda's FarmsClick here for more information about coffees from Hawaii

name: Memory Lane
desc_1: Balanced, deeply sweet-savory. Nutella, plum, jasmine, cedar, maple syrup in aroma and cup. Sweet-savory structure with pert acidity; velvety-smooth mouthfeel. The flavor-saturated finish centers around notes of Nutella and plum with cedar undertones.
desc_2: This blend of coffees from Brazil, Guatemala and Sumatra is Nostalgia Coffee Roasters’ first offering since adding a roasting operation to its successful third-wave mobile coffee shop. Founded by Taylor Fields in 2018, Nostalgia will continue to roll out new coffees for online sale. Visit www.nostalgiacoffeeroasters.com for more information.
desc_3: An engaging, harmonious blend designed to evoke pleasant memories of fine traditional coffee experiences.Explore Similar CoffeesClick here for more reviews from Nostalgia Coffee Roasters

name: Cordillera del Fuego Costa Rica Termico
desc_1: Bright, sweetly spice-toned. Cinnamon, candy apple, grapefruit zest, freesia-like flowers, a hint of fresh yogurt in aroma and cup. Sweet-tart structure with lively, high-toned acidity; crisp, satiny mouthfeel. The finish continues spice-toned and rich.
desc_2: Produced by Don Luis Campos of Cordillera del Fuego and processed by the “thermic” method, in which beans, with skins removed, are heated with some of the fruit flesh or mucilage still adhering to them. The exposure to heat starts to break down the natural sugars of the mucilage, partially caramelizing it. This coffee was imported by Genuine Origin, a specialty-focused coffee importer based in Irvington, New York. Collage Coffee is a micro-roastery featuring specialty coffee and house brewed kombucha. Colläge works with local artists to promote fine arts in its region, and loves serving its community. This coffee is available for purchase at the Collage store and cafe, 221 South Broad Street, Grove City, Pennsylvania.
desc_3: A deeply sweet Costa Rica coffee processed by an unusual variation on the honey method, promoting a pleasingly nuanced profile with a range of spice notes supported by subtly tart, yogurt-like hints.Explore Similar CoffeesClick here for more reviews from Collage CoffeeClick here for more information about coffees from Costa Rica
